intro: Balsamorhiza macrophylla var. terebinthacea, commonly known as the giant plantain, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its large, basal leaves that can reach up to 30 inches in length, with a waxy, grayish-green surface. The plant produces tall, branched stems that bear yellow flowers in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along streambanks. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and traditional herbal uses.
